0.question:
Suppose The Rolling Stones are going to release a new album next year. Which is more likely:
(a) The album won't chart in any country.
(b) The album won't chart in any country but their world tour sells out all the major venues.
0.target_answer: (a) The album won't chart in any country
0.init_model_answer:
To avoid falling into the conjunction fallacy trap, we need to approach this problem through a purely probabilistic lens, ignoring any anecdotal details about The Rolling Stones or their popularity.

The key principle is that the probability of two events occurring together (a conjunction) can never exceed the probability of either individual event occurring alone.

In this case, option (b) describes a conjunction of two events:
1) The album won't chart in any country
2) Their world tour sells out all major venues

For this conjunction to occur, both of those events must happen together. 

On the other hand, option (a) describes just the first event happening alone:
1) The album won't chart in any country

Mathematically, we know that:
P(Event 1 AND Event 2) ≤ P(Event 1)

So the probability of the conjunction in (b) can never exceed the probability of the single event in (a).

Therefore, to avoid the conjunction fallacy, the correct answer is (a) - it is more likely that the album simply won't chart in any country than the combined scenario in (b).
